segments.text: There are some rolls here, by the way.
Oh, no, thanks.
There's a go.
And when I did, I never cooked, so I wasn't using the kitchen in my apartment.
So I just made the kitchen into an office.
But it's adequate for me, but it isn't much of a place to entertain anybody.
Yeah, I understand that.
That's why I suggested coming down here.
This is fine.
It's not any problem, really.
Now, after the plant closes down, then what do you do?
Where do you go from there?
You stay with Bureau of Mines?
Well, I was already here.
At the time, I was in charge of engineering here.
So I was just on a leave of absence to the State Department for this Pakistan plant, mainly because it was a coal plant.
required oxygen and required low-temperature liquefaction, both of which, again, are compression processes.
So I came back here.
Some of the people from out there stayed on.
Most of them got out of their jobs.
They were pretty much in demand, really.
And it was back in the days when government salaries weren't too good.
Well, see, Cattell left for a couple years, and then he came back.
His job was primarily on costing.
He set up a cost group here.
And he retired about a little over a year ago.
So of the group out there, there's, I don't know of any, but everybody's gone.
A couple of them came back and worked at the anthracite station, but they're gone.
Kenny and Bircher.
But they're both retired.
Mr. Wainwright?
Wainwright was never out there.
I see.
He was here.
I see.
He just retired this year.
He had a gas purification program here.
In fact, the gas purification that we used on the Fisher-Tropsch plant out there was pretty much what they had developed here, and it worked okay.
I was the resident engineer on the Fisher-Tropsch plant.
It was a copper project, and it was designed in Pittsburgh.
Copper didn't move engineering in like Bexhill did.
They wanted somebody to go out.
So again, being single, I spent a better part of a year out here.
And then toward the end, we were starting up the plant.
So then Cattell come out and finished up the job.
But my job was primarily buying equipment for the Fisher-Groves plant.
And since it was all of the compressors and a lot of the pumps were on steam,
So that was one reason they wanted me to come back here on account of my esteemed background.
Why the cost studies on the plan, I wonder?
Why?
Why the cost studies on the plan?
Well, the idea of making theall of our work, we always tried to extrapolate to see whetherI mean, the only way that you can direct research is to
look out ahead and see where you're going.

And I mean, if you've got something that works the best thing in the world and you find out that, one, you can't scale it up, or two, if you do scale it up, it's going to be so expensive nobody will ever want it, you better get into some other type of research.
And that's, in effect, what happened.
Well, yeah, it was pretty obvious.
Well, two things happened.
One, there were two different plants.
it was pretty obvious that the coal hydro plant, the pressure was just plain too high.
And on the Fisher Toast plant, that was already being picked up.
Keith built a plant, which never operated for very long, down in Brownsville, Texas, Fisher Toast plant.
And then the next step was that they built these big ones in South Africa.
So actually, all of the gasoline and oil that's been built by
made from coal synthetically has all been made after the war was all by Fischer-Tropsch.
Which never worked well for the Germans.
Well, see, there was a reason for it, and that was that the Germans, this was back in the propeller plane days, and the thing that the Germans wanted was very high octane.
And the coal hydro made it.
So see, all their aviation gasoline was made of coal hydro.
And the Fisher-Tropes in those days, and still does as far as that goes, makes a wide spectrum.
With the coal hydro, you can pretty much tailor it.
But with the Fisher-Tropes, you make a wide spectrum.
And they made everything.
They made alcohol, and they made butter, and they made gasoline.
But most of their synthetics were made from coal hydro rather than FT.
The big advantage of FT was, of course, the pressure.
You can go out and buy the equipment off the shelf.
Did you ever run into problems with IG Farben, conflict of patents or conflicts of...
If they did, I know nothing about it.
As far as I know now, I think we just adopted the attitude that we wanted to order.
That's my impression.
Of course, I was over there afterward.
In fact, I even spent some time with IG Farben.
One of the things I was interested in on this Pakistan job was utilizing the Winkler gasifiers rather than the Lergy's, since the Lergy's made a lot of methane.
I didn't particularly want the methane, but I found out that theeverything was pretty much cut and dried, so we ended up with Lergy's.
But I did spend some time at thewell, this wasactually, I said IG Farben.
Actually, it wasn't.
It was the BASF at Ludwigshaben.
And I knew Dr. Flesch in those days, and he'd very much like to put in some
But unfortunately, we ended upthat was the only Mooney plant I know that ever used Lurgies.
Did you use any other variations, like Schmalfeld?
Schmalfeld was never very practical.
In fact, we did some work here with an offshoot of it, in which weof course, the idea of the Schmalfeld was that you recycled hot gases.
We always found that no matter what we did, we still had to use oxygen, so we cut it out.
And, of course, it didn't come on in a new dress under Penn Income, but it was new.
The gasification processes that were really practical in Germany were the clergy for town gas in the winter for synthetic fuels.
Copper's toxic came along.
In fact, we had copper.
In fact, we had toxic out at Louisiana and Missouri.
We had a copper's toxic gas fire out there, but the thing never worked because he insisted on bringing the
the coal in with the oxygen, and it was always blowing up and catching on fire.
So we finally got rid of it.
But since that time, it's become a viable process.
And I guess most of the ammonia around the world that's made from coal has been made with copper's toxic.
And I understand that the ERDA is just going to contract to, I guess, the coppers for a copper's toxic for a hydrogen plant.
Where do you pull such vast amounts of hydrogen from?
Where?
Where do you pull that from?
You always get it from water.
I see.
That's the name of it.
You know, washer stuff.
Yes, that's right.
Always comes from water.
What you do, you trade carbon for hydrogen if you're going all the way with coal.
In fact, hydrogen gave Germany, without their hydrogen technology, Germany couldn't have fought either world war.
So you end up with what, CO, just CO gas?
Well, you make CO and hydrogen and then use the water gas shift to shift the CO to hydrogen and CO2 and wash out the CO2.
Any more questions?
Did you inquire what's
I wanted to continue that.
Now, after, let's say now, we're talking about 1952, right?
Is that about when you leave the plant?
We shut down the plant in 1952.
I left in 1952 to go overseas.
The plant was shut down July 1, 1953, and I'm still over there.
I came back in September of that year.
And then what do you do?
Then you come back to work here?
I came back to work here and finished up the plant here.
Okay.
And then we moved out there in 1954.
Yeah.
So I was still working on the engineering and construction of this plant when I came back.
And then you consult for private industry then?
Then?
No, I couldn't.
I worked for the Bureau.
So you don't begin to consult for Diamond Shamrock then until after?
I never consulted for Diamond Shamrock.
I just happened to be interested in their
Oh, OK. And the fact that they've got a plant here.
And I've always been interested in these metallurgical processes.
And the thing I found out was that they were having, I understand, having some trouble getting natural gas.
And I thought that there was some talk, and again, this is forehand, that they might move the whole operation over here at Kingwood.
And I was interested in that, if indeed I could help.
That's the two-stage hydrogenation.
I'm not really too sure about it, exactly how they do it.
I think the hydrogenation work was done over in Maryland, and then the product was shipped here, and I think it was an electric furnace the rest of the way, but I'm not 100 percent sure.
The only thing I'm interested in, what was interesting, was making hydrogen from coal
natural gas.
I worked for the guy that developed the natural gas reforming, Shapley.
But now it'swe've got to go the other way.
See, that's one of the things.
All these plants that have been built, nobody has ever faced up to making the hydrogen.
Louisiana, Missouri, we got it from ourwe call them cracking furnaces.
They call them reformers now.
And then all these other plants have been built.
solvent-refined coal, and high gas, and all of them, they've always gotten the hydrogen from reforming natural gas, because it's an easy way to do it.
So nobody's really faced up to it.
Is this the high gas process that started IGT?
Yeah, that's right.
They've gotten away from the hydrogenation now.
It's pretty much an oxygen process, pretty much like xanthine, really.
For whom do you consult?
For whom do you consult?
Just anybody.
Primarily mechanical technology.
And then I also consult for two groups for Gilbert.
And then I consult for Rocketdyne and Argonne Lab.
But, you know, it's one of these things.
I just work when they want me to.
I work, I guess, about seventy days a year.
And then put another thirty.
Another thirty, huh?
That's a nice job.
And then another thirty.
Well, see, I had thirty-three years in the government at a fairly high grade.
It actually wouldn't pay me to work for the government anymore.
I could make about as much as I retired as I could work.
That's many years.
I just do this as a hobby, really.
I could probably
I've never looked for somebody who wants me fined.
In fact, amazingly, last year, an awful lot of my work has been MHD.
